title: How far should you trust that snowflake symbol when winter tire shopping?
text:
Now that winter is closing in on us, you’re likely looking to buy some snow tires for your vehicle — three Canadians of four put them on their car, after all. If that statistic sounds high, and if you assume it’s because 100 per cent of Quebec motorists drive on winter tires by law, well — nope, that’s not it.

Quebec’s made snow tires mandatory since 2008, so it’s got nothing to do with the major jumps in winter tires use nearly every province has registered in the past four years, as broken down here by the Tire and Rubber Association of Canada (TRAC).

In British Columbia, 64 per cent of drivers now use winter tires, up from just 38 percent in 2014. Moving across the country, those numbers are:

Alberta: 70% (up from 45% in 2014)

Saskatchewan and Manitoba: 60% (up from 39% in 2014)

Ontario: 69% (up from 56% in 2014)

Quebec: 100%

Maritimes: 94% (up from 73% in 2014)

Canada: 76% (up from 58% in 2014)

Is the snowflake — fake?

So clearly, Canadians want winter tires. And if we had to bet, the sidewall snowflake symbol – the 3PMSF, as the industry calls this pictogram, born in North America two decades ago – is likely helping them separate all-season or all-weather tires from the winter rubber they really want, tires that’ll stick when the temperature drops below 7°C — or much, much colder.

It’s -30°C that morning? It shouldn’t be a problem for your winter tires. In fact, “instead of thinking of winter tires only as ‘snow tires’, you may want to start thinking of them as ‘cold-weather tires,’” TRAC suggests. Okay, gotcha.

But that alpine symbol tells you only about a minimum. Precisely, it guarantees these winter tires’ traction is at least 10-per-cent superior compared to all-season tires when put through the Transport-Canada-approved ASTM F1805 test. (“ASTM” stands for “American Standard Test Method.”)

You read that right: only 10 per cent better traction.

The symbol says nothing about superior performance in low temperatures, notes Sylvain Légaré, automotive expert at CAA-Quebec. In fact, some all-season truck tires with aggressive treads can wear the Three-Peak Mountain Snowflake symbol even if their compound will not keep cold-weather tires’ flexibility when the mercury drops.

Beside, this test is conducted on medium-packed-snow surfaces, and only while accelerating in a straight line. Nothing, again, is said or tested or established or measured about accelerating on ice – more common in cities – or on that 80cm of fluffy snow that fell over Calgary 10 days ago.

What really interests us in winter-y conditions is the braking aptitudes, right? Sadly, no industry or government test measures stopping distances, on snow or on ice. Same thing for tires while veering or skidding.

But have patience: A new testing procedure is under development, part of an effort to create an ISO standard that will measure a tire’s grip on an icy surface, says Barry Yutronkie, Director of Operations for TRAC.

“Once a standard is created (perhaps in a few years’ time) industry will have the tool by which a common benchmark can be established,” says Yutronkie. “But right now, it is a little premature to know the outcome. Perhaps this will evolve into a marking on the tire or some other method to identify the ice capability of tire.”

The good new (and the bad news)

The good news: You’re not condemned to buy crappy winter tires. Manufacturers are moving beyond those performance minimums via new compounds, treads and avant-garde technologies like “microbites” — engineered from crushed walnut shells.

“Many tires in the market today achieve levels approaching 130 per cent [better than all-season] so there can be quite a range between tires that meet the minimum and the ones that perform at the higher levels,” explains Yutronkie.

The bad news: You’ll have to work harder than just walking into any big-box store a few hours before a snowstorm to hastily choose what you think is the best quality-priced winter tires.

(We shop for a new car for weeks, even months, comparing models, options, reading reviews — how come we don’t put half that effort into buying the only thing keeping that well-chosen car on the road?)

Your winter tires can’t do it all

The best “cold-weather tire” advice we can give you? First off, since a set of four winter rubbers will last you an average 40,000 km (three or four years) make the effort to visit a couple of tire stores. (Also, yes, you want four snow tires, not only two. Otherwise, you’ll affect your vehicle’s stability and, in the long run, the whole integrity of your vehicle’s traction systems.)

Shop way before arrives the “realistic date” for your city and find a few models that will suit your needs. Some criteria to consider, suggests (former ice racer) Sylvain Légaré of CAA-Quebec:

What do you drive? A small car, a performance car, an intermediate SUV, a giant pickup?

Where do you drive? In cities, on highway, in rural county — all of the above?

How do you drive, and on what? Snow? Packed snow? Ice? Black ice? Do you tow?

How many kilometers do you “winter-drive” on average?

How much do you want to pay?

Drop from your shopping list any models that don’t meet any of your criteria, recommends Légaré and then prioritize the rest of your tire wants and needs. Because sadly, “your winter tires can’t do it all,” says Légaré. Choose the longer-lasting budget-minded tires and you may sacrifice the comfort of the quieter ones.

Thinking of studded tires? Légaré notes the tech on those has improved so much recently, some of those crampons can even retract until needed. (Please remember some condo parking garages and municipalites ban them, though, and that in Quebec, they’re allowed only from October 15 to May 1.)

So, what is the best tire?

What a question. As when asking “what’s the best car?” there’s no easy answer. To start, though, Consumer Reports‘ top five recommendations for cars specifically are the:

Cooper Discoverer True North (score of 70)

Hankook Winter i*Cept iZ2 (70)

Continental Winter Contact SI (69)

Michelin X-Ice XI3 (68)

Nokian Hakkapeliita R3 (68)

The magazine also offers subscribers recommended winter tires for trucks and recommended performance vehicle winter/snow tires. Note those recommendations all have a flaw, though: Despite being “Excellent” to “Good” in many aspects (handling, snow traction, ride comfort and noise) all do “Poor” or at best “Fair” in wet braking and dry braking.

Ice, ice, baby

You have to know Consumer Reports, based in Connecticut, is testing winter tires in a local indoor ice skating ring. “We test the braking from 10 mph (16 km/h) and no, we never crashed a car — although we sometimes came very close,” Eugene Petersen, Consumer Reports’ tire program manager, told us.

Sylvain Légaré doesn’t believe too much in this “indoor” ice testing. “If you want my personal advice, the ice of a skating rink is never as slippery as black ice or wet ice. If you play hockey, you know you can walk on ice without falling. Try this after an ice storm on your city’s streets!”

So what does Légaré in all his ice racing driver experience recommend for winter tires? “The Pirelli Ice Zero FR, the Nokian Hakkapeliitta, the Michelin X-Ice and the Toyo GSi-6 with its crushed walnut shells.” (We weren’t joking about the walnut tech.)

Better yet, what does Légaré stick on the rims of his own daily driver? The highest-end studded winter tires he can find. Period.
description: The Three-Peak Mountain Snowflake symbol only guarantees some performance minimums, but if you don’t want to feel like you’re driving a hockey puck on ice this year, here's…
